article_title: Sanders’ plan for free college might not suit California

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Kurtis Alexander
article_metadata.description: Too much of the federal money that would come to California to pay for Sanders’ plan, policy experts say, would go to tuition for rich students — Sanders’ proposal covers anyone attending a public college or university.  “There are two ways to think about spending additional higher education dollars,” explained Hans Johnson, a senior fellow at the Public Policy Institute of California and director of the organization’s higher education center.  About 57 percent of undergraduates in the University of California system pay nothing, while about 75 percent get a free ride in the state university system.  What would really boost college opportunities for Californians, say Johnson and others, is helping low-income students pay their nontuition costs like living expenses, which are a common deterrent to college, as well as building out the state’s public university systems.  Though Sanders’ plan, as laid out in legislation proposed last year, might not be ideal for California or other states, it’s helping spotlight the important issue of college affordability, something that’s never been such a big issue in a presidential contest.  “I want every child in this state and Vermont and in America to know that if he or she takes their schoolwork seriously, does well in school, that regardless of their income, they will be able to get to college at a public college or university tuition-free,” Sanders told The Chronicle.  Sanders’ proposal calls for the federal government to pay states two-thirds the cost of public tuition and fees, or about $47 billion a year, with that money generated from a tax on stock, bond and derivative transactions.
